Prairie State has evacuation plans for which mandatory personnel training is performed with all employees and contractors.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

Prairie State has a Management of Change policy to govern safety improvements to both equipment and work practices involving anhydrous ammonia.  The policy requires employee stakeholders to periodically review and revise the Risk Management Plan, the physical anhydrous ammonia system, and operation and maintenance procedures.

Executive Summary

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Prairie State Generating Company, LLC (Prairie State) is committed to the health and safety of employees through implementation of a comprehensive program designed to protect workers from industrial hazards.  The health and safety program includes chemical hazards.  This program is a top priority for Prairie State.  Success depends on the alertness and personal commitment of all.

Prairie State provides information to employees about workplace safety and health issues through regular internal communication channels such as supervisor-employee meetings, bulletin board postings, memos or other written communications. It is the responsibility of all employees to develop proper safety work attitudes and adhere to all safety rules, be aware of potential worksite hazards, and to be informed and trained about safety issues.

Employees and supervisors receive periodic workplace safety training. The training covers potential safety and health hazards, safe work place practices and procedures to eliminate or minimize hazards. These are provided to increase awareness and allow employees to function within a safe working environment.  Employees shall not perform work where known chemical hazards exist unless they have received safety training for those job functions.  All employees receive emergency response awareness training for the anhydrous ammonia system. 

A safety committee composed of hourly employees, supervisors, managers and other representatives from throughout the organization will be established to help monitor the Company's safety program, to address accident preventability, and to facilitate effective communications between employees and management about workplace safety and health issues.

Regulated Substances Handled

Prairie State Generating Station maintains one substance, anhydrous ammonia, on site in amounts exceeding the Risk Management Program (RMP) threshold

quantities.  Anhydrous ammonia is to be used in the selective catalytic reduction air pollution control devices installed on Prairie State's two utility boilers.  

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention
  
Prairie State has operation, maintenance and inspection procedures for the anhydrous ammonia system that are designed to prevent accidental releases.  Personnel will receive training before being allowed to work on the systems.

The ammonia systems will be visually inspected on a daily basis.  Standard operating procedures for startup, shutdown, normal operation and emergency operation of the ammonia storage systems will be in place when operation begins. The procedures will be written and posted in appropriate areas.  Personnel will be trained annually on safety concerns and general operation procedures as well as emergency procedures. 

Ammonia sensors and alarms are in place to detect an anhydrous ammonia release.  A water deluge control system serves as the primary means of mitigating an airborne anhydrous ammonia release around the storage tanks. 

Prairie State performed process hazard assessments using a 'What If' type analysis for the anhydrous ammonia system.  This analysis utilizes a brainstorming approach, in which a team of people familiar with the process asks questions about possible undesirable events.  The What If analysis results in a listing of undesirable events with their consequences, safeguards, and recommendations for risk reduction.  Comments and recommendations are summarized in the Process Hazard Assessment section of the Risk Management Program.

Five-Year Accident History

The facility has had no ammonia releases in the past five years. 

Emergency Response Program
